bibl.title: Letter from Robert U. Patterson to William Duffield Robinson, July 17, 1925

div1.p: Patterson corrects Robinson's statement that Gorgas discovered the means of transmission for yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Robert U. Patterson to William Duffield Robinson, July 17, 1925
div1.opener:
rup ell
S. G. O.
July 17, 1925.
Dr. William Duffield Robinson,
2012 Mount Vernon Street,
Philadelphia.
My dear Dr. Robinson:
div1.p:
I have just received your paper read before the Sydenham Coterie
of Philadelphia on the subject “Prolongation of Life”. I thank you for it
very much and note that you were most generous in giving credit to General
Ireland and myself for helping you obtain some data with regard to disabil-
ities that were found to exist during the examination of the draft during
the war. In reading the paper over, however, I notice one statement which
begins at the foot of page 5 and is carried over to page 6, which I think
inadvertently you have not made quite correctly. You say --

“Too great honor cannot be given to General Gorgas for his
effort resulting in the discovery of the means by which the
yellow fever germ is propagated and distributed.”

What really happened was this: Some time during the eighties Dr. Carlos
Finlay of Havana, Cuba, advanced the theory that in his opinion yellow fever
was probably a mosquito borne disease. However it was only an opinion and
he never did anything either to prove or disprove it. The U. S. Yellow Fever
incorrect
Commission, of which Walter Reed was the Chairman, conducted experiments in
1899 and 1900 and 1901 which absolutely proved that yellow fever was transmitted by a
mosquito (Stegomyia fasciata) and in no other way. Of course those experiments
are known to you and all other well informed medical men and were classical.
Based on the discovery of Walter Reed and his co-workers that the mosquito was
the only transmitting agent, Gorgas, at that time Chief Health Officer of the
Port of Havana, Cuba, inaugurated sanitary measures which lead to the eradica-
tion of yellow fever from Havana at that time. There was a brief outbreak again
about 1906, which was quickly wiped out under the administration of Colonel Kean,
then Sanitary advisor to the Provisional Government of Cuba. General Gorgas con-
tinued his excellent practical sanitary measures in the Panama Canal Zone and
of course it was that work which made it possible to build the Canal, although
the actual construction was carried out by engineers.

I am sure you will not think me presuming to bring to your attention the
incorrectness of the statement you made in your article, but having full knowl-
edge of the facts I feel certain you would wish me to do so. The fact that
Reed and his co-workers made the actual discovery of the cause and method of
transmission of yellow fever does not in any way detract from the monumental
work of General Gorgas. There is truly glory enough for all. I think your
article is most interesting and quite timely.
